reviewText:
Product received for free

Antiflux
DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing.

Antiflux is a game about making it to the end of the stage and progressing to newer stages using the abilities you come across, as well as solving puzzles that are in your way. This 2D puzzle-platformer also falls under a metroidvainia category, which means that there's quite a bit of exploring and backtracking that can be done with the discovery of new abilities. This also means that there are different ways to complete puzzles depending on what abilities you choose to use.

--------

Graphics: 6 / 10

The art assets are fine. Though nothing really stuck out as amazing" to me
date: there is a lot of nice background scenes and terrains that look pretty cool. The art-style is suitable for the theme of the game
recommended: and there are nice visuals when using skills and abilities. The background and foreground are not cluttered
hoursPlayed: which is a good thing. This allows the player to focus on the objects that are needed to progress
helpfulPercent: or which platforms to jump on. The game's graphics are not that demanding
votesHelpful:
meaning that most cards and CPUs should run the game smoothly.

--------

Sound: 6 / 10

The Antiflux soundtrack is quite nice. The melodies range from calming and soothing ambient sounds to more intense or upbeat tracks. You can listen to the OST for free on the developer's Soundcloud page. The sound assets are fine and none of the sound effects or background music get repetitive unless you spend a prolonged period of time within the stage. Although none of the music in the game really grabbed me
votesTotal:
it still wasn't bad.

--------

Mechanics: 7 / 10

The mechanics of the game are really solid
votesFunny: and this is where the game shines. Like many games in this genre
commentsCount: you start off with no real abilities
column17: you gain new skills. Using these skills
column18: you can progress even further and overcome obstacles. There are many obstacles such as enemy robots that move in a certain way
column19: portals you and the enemy can use
column22:
teleporters and lasers. I'm sure there are more challenges and objects as the game continues on.

The puzzle element of the game gets more and more difficult as you progress and really makes you think hard sometimes. You instantly die if you''re hit by a laser or enemy so you have to plan your moves carefully. There are also some obstacles that change the level permanently (until you die or reset the level of course). The puzzles are designed well and give you a satisfying feeling once you complete them.

--------

Personal Final Remarks:

Antiflux is one of those games that I feel like; if you try it
column24: you'll continue to crave that satisfying feeling of accomplishment. It could keep you playing for longer than you expect. Despite this
column25: puzzle-platformers are not games that I enjoy very much. Probably since I'm awful at puzzle games in general and I get frustrated easily. So although this game might not be for me
column26: I could see how many others would enjoy it. It also keeps track of the time it took you to complete certain stages within the game itself
column27: so it's also a game for speed runners to take part in.\n\nThanks to the Devs for giving me the opportunity to review the game
column28: as well as anyone who took this review into consideration

reviewText: As far as mobile ports go, this isn't that bad. The puzzles are challenging and force you to think, but are still fun. The game is a little buggy, the visuals aren't the best, and I had trouble understanding the story. Still though, its a fun game that's worth checking out, especially when its on sale.
